comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: This is actually much sharper that the other shot though not enough to be definitive about the time which I take to be 1205? but I wouldn't bet on it.  The architect/town planner had a great eye for setting off his building to perfection, the line of Georgian houses leading down to the elegant church with clock tower at the end, very nice view.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] It is lovely, like the gorgeous view down Upper Mount Street to the Pepper Cannister church. And taken later in the day, as the awning has been unfurled at Field's?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
Aeroplane Disaster?  "On 5th July 1912, Captain E.B. Loraine and Staff-Sergeant R.H.V. Wilson were killed near the junction of the A344, A360 and B3086 grid reference SU098429. They were flying a Nieuport Monoplane and when making a tight turn the aeroplane plunged toward the ground and crashed."

Edit: Does this billboard say "Daily News and Leader"? The paper was only called that from sometime in 1912, when the Daily News merged with the Morning Leader.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Just double-checked original, and it is indeed the Daily News & Leader!! So, changing to Circa 1912 for both of these photos. But going to leave the question mark in situ for a wee while longer, though 1912 is looking very promising, especially given your Aeroplane Disaster find above...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: I firmly believe that there are no dogs in this photo..........

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The London Times of 6th July 1912 reports not only the disaster the previous day, but also has an entry in the deaths column for Capt. Loraine, an obituary, and an account of the inquest, which took place on the evening of the 5th (the same day as the accident), and concludes with the verdict of the jury. They didn't hang around in those days.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
There were 2 other air disasters in 1912 involving RFC airmen.
6th Sep 1912: Captain P Hamilton and 2nd Lieutenant Wyness-Stewart in a Deperdussin monoplane near Hitchin
10th Sep 1912: Lieutenants Hitchkiss and Bettington in a Bristol monoplane near Oxford

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Danny that was the year after a certain Asian nation opened their first restaurant in the north side:-)  The two photographs are a noticably dog free zone!

comment.author: 44274283@N07
comment._content: That view now sadly viewable no longer, the pretty Georgians were torn down to wake way for an Amsterdam School social housing development, which is interesting in it's own right, but nearly as elegant as the buildings we see here.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] So are we back at July 1912 then, despite the Opening of Parliament headline??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I don't think these photos are from the same date. This one has strong sunshine, sun just East of South, high in the sky, awnings out to shade the shopwindows, so midday in July would fit. The other has the sun  from the South, but no sun on the footpath, and shadows on the facades indicate the sun is at a lower angle. I think the other photo is midday in October.

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/44274283@N07] 

The row from North Frederick St down as far as where Frederick Ct crosses Hardwicke St are the same buildings.

comment.author: 62200949@N03
comment._content: this looks just like Prince regent street in leith, Edinburgh. looking up too north leith parish church on Madeira street, check out the sign on the wall above the shop on the right, it says Edinburgh!. google map it for a comparison of city planning.
